record.title: Two
record.detail: The name 'Capitol' has remained constant for many years, but the uses of this building have varied. It has hosted live theatre, circus, cinema, and currently is a favourite location for musicals. Originally it was a market building.

record.title: Capitol Theatre (Building)
record.detail: Market, circus, picture palace and now theatre, the Capitol has a chequered history.

record.title: Malaysians
record.detail: From transported convicts to pearl fishermen and food hawkers, Malaysians have long had ties with Sydney. Today they form a prominent part of the daily fabric in the cultural and business life of the city.

record.title: Capitol Theatre (Building)
record.detail: Market, circus, picture palace and now theatre, the Capitol has a chequered history.

record.title: Theatre
record.detail: European theatre in Sydney began before the first Fleet made landfall, with a convict play on board the Scarborough. While theatre was always popular, a commercial theatre scene did not emerge until the 1830s, and theatrical fortunes rose and fell with the city's prosperity.

record.title: Capitol Theatre (Building)
record.detail: Market, circus, picture palace and now theatre, the Capitol has a chequered history.

record.title: Haymarket
record.detail: Once a convenient stopping place for bullock carts, the Haymarket traditionally attracted cheap housing and entertainment to service its many markets. Many such elements remain in a modern guise as the theatre district and Chinatown have expanded into the area.

record.title: Capitol Theatre (Building)
record.detail: Market, circus, picture palace and now theatre, the Capitol has a chequered history.

record.title: Capitol Theatre building
record.detail: Built on the original site of Paddy's Market, the Capitol Theatre was originally built as the New Belmore Markets, and converted into a Hippodrome for the Wirth Bros Circus when the markets moved to Thomas Street, closer to Darling Harbour. For 10 years the building was a circus venue, with a seal pool and elephant enclosure. From 1926-28 the building was rebuilt again, as a picture palace in the 'atmospheric' style. Despite threats of demolition in the 1960s and 70s, the Capitol has been retained and restored as a lyric theatre.

record.title: Capitol Theatre (Building)
record.detail: Market, circus, picture palace and now theatre, the Capitol has a chequered history.

record.title: New Tivoli Theatre
record.detail: The last theatre built in Sydney before World War I, called the Adelphi until 1916 and Grand Opera House until 1932, the 'Tiv' as it became known was a venue for melodrama, vaudeville, pantomime and more, until the 1960s.

record.title: Capitol Theatre (Building)
record.detail: Market, circus, picture palace and now theatre, the Capitol has a chequered history.

record.title: Circus
record.detail: Circus has been part of Sydney's entertainment since the 1840s and hardly a year has passed since then without a circus in town. Sydney performers have gone on to international careers in the arena and have returned triumphant, and circus skills and acts became part of the city's thriving vaudeville and theatre scene.

record.title: Capitol Theatre (Building)
record.detail: Market, circus, picture palace and now theatre, the Capitol has a chequered history.

record.title: White, Henry Eli, Position, Architect, Capitol Theatre
White, Henry Eli (Person)
record.detail: Theatre architect who designed some of Sydney's best known theatres during the 1920s, as well as the Bunnerong power station.

record.title: Capitol Theatre (Building)
record.detail: Market, circus, picture palace and now theatre, the Capitol has a chequered history.

record.title: Capitol Theatre building
record.detail: Built on the original site of Paddy's Market, the Capitol Theatre was originally built as the New Belmore Markets, and converted into a Hippodrome for the Wirth Bros Circus when the markets moved to Thomas Street, closer to Darling Harbour. For 10 years the building was a circus venue, with a seal pool and elephant enclosure. From 1926-28 the building was rebuilt again, as a picture palace in the 'atmospheric' style. Despite threats of demolition in the 1960s and 70s, the Capitol has been retained and restored as a lyric theatre.

record.title: Laila Ellmoos
record.detail: Laila Ellmoos is an historian with the City of Sydney’s History Program. She is the author of three books including Our Island Home: a history of Peat Island. Laila is the current President of the Professional Historians Association of NSW, and is a regular presenter on Fbi Radio’s Scratching Sydney’s Surface, a segment that explores the history of Sydney.

record.title: Sydney's
record.detail: Located on the site of the Belmore Markets and the Wirth Brothers Hippodrome, the Capital Theatre has experienced periods of revival and neglect as fashions in entertainment have changed since its establishment in 1928.

record.title: Heritage Council of New South Wales
record.detail: Heritage Council of New South Wales

record.title: Much
record.detail: The highly decorative interiors of the Capitol Theatre were intended to give an illusion of an Italian open air garden in which to watch silent films. The theatre gradually fell into disrepair after its grand opening in 1928 and it was not until the 1990s that conservation work was carried out. It was officially reopened in 1996 as a lyric theatre.
IM interior Capitol Theatre IN EM but a better detail of decor if possible.
